events.target_title: Support using GPG-encrypted password for unlocking the keyring
Add support for JMAP protocol
Add support for JMAP protocol
Add support for JMAP protocol

note.body:
> Citation needed for this statement.Citation needed for this statement.

*We started the JMAP process in 2014, by talking to everyone we could find — at conferences, online, even visiting companies directly and chatting to our counterparts in their email teams! With these discussions we validated that there was interest in a modern, open standard for email which could give a user experience as good as or better than proprietary alternatives.* (source: [JMAP is on the home straight](https://fastmail.blog/2018/12/27/jmap-is-on-the-home-straight/), FastMail blog, Dec 27, 2018)

> Nowhere I'm afraid, until there is an RFC standard which defines JMAP.

The [JSON Meta Application Protocol](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-jmap-core/) and [JMAP (JSON Meta Application Protocol) for Mail](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-jmap-mail/) are still drafts, yes, but they have undergone several revisions since the IETF JMAP working group started in early 2017 and are expected to become standards in early 2019.

> For questions please use the mailing list: https://mail.gnome.org/mailman/listinfo/evolution-list

I think this one is more useful for tracking in an issue tracker since interested Evolution users will more easily find the status of JMAP support.
Also, it may take a while between updates and current mailing list archive frontends are not good at connecting such periodic updates.

---

I noticed you were quick to close the issue, but I would still like to hear the feedback from Evolution's maintainer, @mcrha.

events.target_title: Place window initially at true top-left
Place window initially at true top-left

note.body:
Well, that was my first idea.

I have tried to do a gnome-shell extension that listens to the *window-added* signal (emitted per workspace) and when received it places the window if that window is the first window on the workspace. Only the first window per workspace needs to be explicitly placed since mutter tries to place new windows next to any already existing windows.

However this doesn't work that good. On *Xorg* it works good, on *wayland* it doesn't. On *wayland* it works something like every ten time.

Correct me if I'm wrong, but what I think (after looking at the mutter code) is happening is that the *window-added* signal is emitted in before mutter has done its window placement. On *Xorg* the mutter window placement actually ends up being completed before the gnome-shell extension *window-added* listener runs, on *wayland* it doesn't most of the time...

Do you have any other ideas on how to do this?

The source code for my *better-window-placement* extension is located here: https://github.com/christensson/gnome-better-window-placement

events.target_title: Strawman proposal for a new generic allocator interface

note.body:
If Rust is not only inspiration, but a possible integration target for this, please be aware of the [approved RFC](https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/1398-kinds-of-allocators.md) adding a generic API for non-global allocators to its standard library. The API is [being further developed](https://doc.rust-lang.org/nightly/std/alloc/trait.Alloc.html) as an unstable feature. Of particular interest are `usable_size` and `alloc_excess`.

If non-global, per-container allocators will become a thing in Rust, it would likely be difficult to integrate them with the thread-local stacked design.

events.target_title: Make dialog for estimated copy/delete/transfer time auto-resizing

note.body:
Ok, so to sum it up there is 2 lines which need to be ellipsed better:

*  The actual task (e.g.: "Copying 1,146 files to Internal Storage")
*  The progress information (e.g.: "3/1,146 - approximately 596,523 hours left (0 bytes per second")

I think we need different approaches for each line. For the task-line i would ellipse it like this:

"Copying files to Internal...orage"

The amount of text which gets ellipsed from the target path can be different. This is just a draft. I think it is in *any case* better to show the start of the path and the end, because in most power-user file organisation ideologies, The beginning *and* the end of the path play a major identifying role of the location of files)

For the progress information i imagined something like this:

"3 / 1,146 - approximately 68 years left (0B/s)"

As you can see, the speed ("0B/s") is reduced to its common abbreviation (i hope "B" is correct). The estimated time is intelligently shorted to a more readable and reasonable time unit (for such a large number of hours, i would definitely start using bigger units). If needed, this line can be ellipsed even further:

"3/1,146 - approx. 68 years left (0B/s)"

Or, if the number of files is *really* large:

"3/1.1e03 --approx. 68 years left (0B/s)"

What i also think is need is a tooltip with the full, unabbreviated text when hovering over this dialog box.

A completely alternative, different solution would be to have scrolling text (like in major music players on mobile platforms).

events.target_title: gnome-shell crashes if a modal window closes whilst being dragged
Make current folder search faster

note.body:
As a replacement for type-ahead, nautilus needs to display search results from the current directory before expending any effort at all on searching further (and further searching must not make the GUI unresponsive).

One thing that might contribute to search being slow is that update_file_info is called in extensions for every file. In my experience with my [extension that puts git status emblems on files](https://github.com/chrisjbillington/git_nautilus_icons) in nautilus, the extension returns fast from update_file_info, but if it adds an emblem, Nautilus is slow to render it. Because of this I blacklist folders with large numbers of files (regardless of search).

I note that during search my extension is called thousands of times with filenames that are valid search results before Nautilus displays any search results. Perhaps Nautilus should display the results before asking extensions about them? Or at the very least display results from the current folder, then ask extensions for file_info, then continue. And if the interface is to remain responsive, Nautilus would need to break up the rendering of emblems (if that's the bit that is slow) into smaller chunks, processing any user input in between.

I'm firmly in the "just give us type-ahead back" camp, but if results from the current directory can appear instantly with the GUI remaining responsive, that will cover 80% of use cases for type-ahead. And since hitting "escape" takes you back to the file list in the searched directory with the file selected from the search results highlighted and in context, that covers most of the remaining use cases. It's still not a perfect replacement (the context switch and unrelated files present in the results is jarring, and the "only search the current directory" setting makes it very limited for actual search instead of as a type-ahead replacement), but if gnome devs want it to replace the use cases of type-ahead, it needs to be *fast* for current directory results.

events.target_title: general: Don't allow launching binaries or programs in general

note.body:
A python script with the execute bit set and `#!/usr/bin/env python` or similar at the top is executable and can be run by double-click from Nautilus prior to this change. Same for perl, ruby, etc. Bash is just the default if a script lacks the `#!` comment at the top saying what interpreter to use.

Many executables in linux are implemented this way:

```
$ grep '#! /usr/bin/python' /usr/bin/* | wc -l
59

$ grep '#!/usr/bin/perl' /usr/bin/* | wc -l
236
```

events.target_title: Launch applications (executable files) by double-clicking

note.body:
+1 for removing the ability to launch .desktop files but retaining ability to launch binaries and scripts.

It even looks like in [version 5.33 of the file utility](https://github.com/file/file/blob/master/ChangeLog) PIE executables are now identified as such, resolving [one of the original issues](https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1296858) that prompted reconsideration of supporting binary launching from nautilus. This means there will no longer be an impetus for FireFox to distribute non-PIE executables, so they can be more secure in their binary distribution for linux (the inability to launch PIE executables from linux file managers has been [a problem for them](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1360301)).

Removing the ability to launch .desktop files resolves the CVE fairly definitively, and people seem to be much less concerned about their removal. Not many people are actually launching apps from the desktop it seems, they're using the DE launchers as intended, but many people seem to not necessarily want their random dev scripts, some isolated/portable apps and meticulously sorted folders full of games integrated with the system.

Nautilus doesn't need to change to support the PIE executables (other than rolling back this recent change) as far as I can tell. It looks like 'file' has changed to report both shared objects and executables as executables if they are PIE. While Nautilus may wish to inspect the 'interpreter' flag (once libmagic adds support for exposing this, not clear if they have yet but as indicated [here](https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/file/+bug/1747711) they will in due course) to decide whether an ELF is intended to be executed or linked, I don't really see a problem if it doesn't and if it just executes them all if they have the execute bit set (and the user confirms they want to execute). They're valid executables that can be executed from the command line with `./libfoo.so`, they just usually segfault is all (but some don't and print things to stdout - not super useful without a terminal, but also harmless). Nonetheless if Nautilus thinks shared objects are executables until libmagic exposes the relevant flags for it to check, that's not so bad in the interim.

If the ability to launch executables remains removed entirely, distros and some savvy users will create a launcher program and associate executable formats with it. But this may not be ideal for scripts, since each type will need to be associated separately - the non-executable ones with your text editor and the executable ones with both the text editor and some 'run' or 'run in terminal' launcher programs. It's also not clear to me whether the presence of the executable bit counts as a different file format for the purpose of setting file associations via nautilus. If it doesn't, then one would have the 'run' option with such a custom launcher even if the executable bit is not set. The launcher program, if well designed, would give a GUI error about the execute bit not being set. This situation is actually not so bad, though it a) defeats the purpose of removing executable launching support if distros will just work around it in this way and b) does not allow the current situation where you get a popup asking "open, or run?", which is something I quite like - since you often switch between both with executables and it is easy to forget to right click and select 'open with'. A confirmation generally is good for preventing accidentally running potentially malicious executables too.

One final possibility might be if Nautilus allowed associating multiple programs with a mime type, without a default, such that it asks every time which program to use. That way distros could have a 'run' and 'run in terminal' launcher program associated with executable file types *as well* as the usual program. This is not ideal however, because if it's part of the user-exposed file associations, the user could change it accidentally (setting their game to always open with 'run program' and inadvertently making this the setting for all executables), opening themselves up to accidentally executing things. Probably better that Nautilus continue to treat executables as special.

All things considered, given that the feature (except for .desktop files) is popular enough to be worked around, and given that the workarounds are more likely to result in accidental execution than if Nautilus treats executables as special, it seems like the feature to run executables from a file browser, if it exists at all (which it is too popular not to IMHO), belongs in Nautilus. The PIE problem is mostly resolved and will likely become fully resolved in time (distinguishing between shared objects and PIE executables with the 'interpreter' flag), and the CVE with .desktop files gone.

PS: I am aware saying 'PIE executable' is like saying 'PIN number' but it'd be more confusing not to.

events.target_title: general: Don't allow launching binaries or programs in general

note.body: Admittedly, extracting tarballs preserves the execution bit as set by the person who made the tarball, so the execute bit is not an indication that the user has explicitly trusted the file, so I don't find that argument convincing and I don't mind an additional popup confirming you want to run the file, possibly with an option to trust that file specifically from now on (and just remembered by Nautilus as long as the file exists rather than living in file permissions). There has also been talk by FileRoller devs that users could be presented with a warning upon extracting tarballs containing executables that have their execute bit set. This is a pretty good option IMHO. Also, if the .desktop functionality is removed, then executables will not as easily be able visibly impersonate other file types, reducing the chance of someone being tricked into running one.

events.target_title: Launch applications (executable files) by double-clicking

note.body:
@antoniof yes, they've avoided distributing PIE builds because of it.

It seems to me that a combination of desktop-removal, security concerns about .desktop files and PIE breaking running executables from Nautilus guided the discussions that led to these changes, and though the PIE stuff was something of a fixable bug, it caused the functionality of launching binaries and scripts to sort of get caught in the crossfire as they are conceptually similar to running .desktop files even though their use cases are quite different in practice.

> You would enjoy the exact same advantages if the authors delivered it as a proper app bundle.

On this topic, the firefox devs themselves are likely to need to test their code before they package it - via a tarball or otherwise - so someone is going to be double clicking an executable that wasn't properly packaged (they don't want to actually install it on their system to test it). I know some of my own projects function differently depending on whether sys.stdout is a tty or not (such as setting up logging), so it's important that I can launch them without a terminal to test them properly - with this functionality removed from Nautilus I will either use a different file manager for this or write a script to do the appropriate forking or whatever is required to disconnect from the controlling terminal as if the app was launched from a launcher so I can test. Of course I don't want to install a .desktop file for these programs, as I already have stable versions of them installed on my system and wouldn't want to mix my development testing up with that.

events.target_title: Improve running binaries experience

note.body:
I like this proposal a lot.

A few thoughts:

"Program" is good! Or "binary program" or "executable" or "script" (if it is actually a script) would work IMHO. There's no reason Nautilus should believe the thing being clicked on is a complete application of any kind - it's just a program, who knows what it is? Might be your computer science homework, for all Nautilus knows. So I like this. Definitely helps give the feel that it's not anything endorsed by your OS.

Setting the execute bit might require superuser privileges, if the file is not owned by the user (even though it can be executed as a normal user).

Not sure whether the terminal should remain open after the program quits. If the desire is to give feedback that something happened, this isn't necessary (a terminal flashing up momentarily is a clear sign something happened), but if it's to be able to see program output, it might be good to have the terminal stay open until closed by the user after the program exits (there are a few ways to do this).

Edit: I assume this proposal includes executable text files as well as binary executables, is that right? Nautilus has no way of knowing an executable text file is not just a text file if the execute bit is not set (the #! magic comment might not be present, it's not needed if it's bash, for example), so it should probably not give the context menu option in the case of text files unless the file already has the execute bit set. Otherwise the option will appear on every text file.

Add a minimal implementation of Gtk.Template. See #52

note.body: Why did you opt to use decorators instead of the default `set_template` and `set_template_from_resource`? With those it would have been possible to define a class at first, then expand it with a template when needed. Using decorators means the template is parsed the moment the class is built, which is less flexible. If I understood it correctly, this means I have to move my whole class defintion to a function, so I can do all the initialization stuff before loading the template. It would have been more convenient to have my own class initialization function, that I can run at any time after my class has been defined.

Honor theme's foreground color

note.body:
This breaks on Python 3 (`%x` value needs to be int, not float). Also, the resulting colour string is wrong when the hex value is only one digit (`"#%x%x%x" % (15, 15, 15)` is `#fff` instead of `#0f0f0f`).

To fix these issues you need to use something like

```py
"#%02x%02x%02x" % (int(color.red * 255), int(color.green * 255), int(color.blue * 255))
```

push_data.commit_title: clutter: Avoid unnecessary relayouts in ClutterText

events.target_title: clutter: Avoid unnecessary relayouts in ClutterText
clutter: Avoid unnecessary relayouts in ClutterText

note.body:
Note that I am calling `clutter_text_get_preferred_*`, *not* `clutter_actor_get_preferred_*` in order to avoid the caching done by `ClutterActor`. Also, the call to `clutter_text_dirty_cache()` is still there, so the cached `PangoLayout` is purged. From my understanding of the code, purging the caches is generally also required for redraws as the `PangoLayout` is specific to the exact text that is rendered.

Comparing to the (cached) allocated size is also fine in my opinion, as this is the size previously used for rendering and that's exactly what we want to compare.

Please correct me if anything of this is wrong. Thank you!

events.target_title: clutter: Avoid unnecessary relayouts in ClutterText

note.body: Makes sense. Will fix those, thank you!

events.target_title: Prioritize cover art from MP3 tags of tracks in 'Now Playing'  section
Prioritize cover art from MP3 tags of tracks in 'Now Playing'  section

note.body:
After looking at the code, it is my understanding that Lollypop looks for album art in this order: 
*  Cache
* 'cover.jpg' in album directory
* Tag artwork
* Any image in album directory
* Default artwork

In case of a hit in 2nd, 3rd or 4th case, it caches the matching artwork for fast access next time.

The suggestion is to search for tag artwork first only for displaying in the 'Now Playing' section. So, I guess the cache mechanism will be bypassed only on a track change. Is this too costly a penalty?

@phw I don't think caching tag art for every track is worth just for this minor thing.

note.body:
Looks like it's failing to build `sysdeps/darwin/procio.c`:

```
procio.c:27:10: fatal error: 'glibtop_private.h' file not found
#include "glibtop_private.h"
         ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
1 error generated.
```

There isn't a `sysdeps/darwin/glibtop_private.h`.

events.target_title: Display month names correctly according to the new standard
Display month names correctly according to the new standard

note.body:
>  What you call "old systems" are the latest non-development versions of major distros like Fedora or Ubuntu,

True, by "old" I mean "anything older than 1-2 weeks". This sounds ridiculous today but the comment in the source code will remain for a long time, maybe forever. In one or two years it will sound appropriately.

> > What exactly does "not working correctly" mean?
> 
> I wrote a small test application on F27,

You need F28 (Rawhide) to make it work correctly. If you really need F27 then you need a patched glibc from [my COPR repository](http://copr.fedorainfracloud.org/coprs/rluzynski/genitive/). (Hint: it's reasonable to set up a dedicated virtual machine before installing glibc from an untrusted source.)

> and it looks like the answer to that question is that the format string (i.e. "%OB") is shown instead of the month name.

True, that's what I meant.

>  That's a lot less bad than hitting an assert or crash,

No, there is no assert nor a crash, it just looks ugly, even more ugly than before. Just an unfinished work in progress: like we introduced a new solution but it is not yet working.

> so I lean towards just leaving it like that given that the combination of bleeding-edge gnome-shell plus stable base system should really be limited to people hacking on gnome-shell itself.

True, this merge request should not be backported to the old stable branches, only to the current master which will be included in the next release.

> If we want to deal with it, we could do something like
> ```javascript
>    let hasGenitiveSupport = (new Date().toLocaleFormat('%OB') != '%OB');
>    this._headerFormatWithoutYear = hasGenitiveSupport ? _('%OB') : _('%B');
> ```
> but I suspect that the additional burden on translators outweighs the benefits ...

I definitely agree. There are more possible solutions like detecting the underlying system version and/or patching the source code at build time or using a *polyfill* solution (replacing the default ```Date.toLocaleFormat``` implementation with our custom one) but I think the easiest is to say that *this gnome-shell version requires glibc 2.27 or newer* and let the older versions just expire. We may provide these backward compatibility solutions only if they are really needed.

>  Thanks for the note on BSD btw, people are indeed using gnome-shell on those.

I'm glad to learn this, for them it is even more required (well, actually depending on their locale).

**Note:** Since ```Date.toLocaleFormat()``` is just a wrapper for ```strftime()``` its behavior depends only on the glibc version, does not depend on glib2 or gjs. This means you can apply the patches already (if you like them), you don't have to wait for the [glib2 bug](https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=749206) to be fixed.

events.target_title: Cross compile support

note.body:
Meson support is needed, yes. We will do that at some point, but I decided to submit patches as they're now, for the purpose of 'discussing with upstream' :)

To use it you need to also write and provide wrappers for target hardware emulation. The ones available in Yocto are specific to that, and so are not included. Also, you need to have g-i for the host system already built and installed in the system: the 'cross-compile' g-i build makes use of it. Then just provide the wrappers and the --use-host-gi to ./configure, make sure the toolchain builds for the target (via CC etc.), and things should just work.

events.target_title: Make GtkCssProvider API less confusing

note.body:
There's 2 different issues here:

(1) mutability/functionality of GtkCssProvidrr
I don't want GtkCssProvider to be immutable because they are not on the web, and I would like to be able to latter add APIs like https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CSSStyleSheet to them.

(2) gtk_style_context_add_provider/gtk_style_context_remove_provider
I do very much think the example works - what doesn't work is that the provider isn't inherited by child widgets. I'm very much in favor of changing that, but that requires someone doing surgery on how GtkStyleCascade is used by GtkCssNode.

events.target_title: Public API for widget sizes

note.body:
My idea was:

 `gboolean gtk_widget_get_bounds(GtkWidget *widget, GtkWidget *other_widget, graphene_rect_t *out_bounds)`
That one should return widget's size (I'm not sure if it should be the border box or the allocated size, but I'm favoring the latter). Note that widget == other_widget should work and basically replace get_allcoated_size().
Return value is %TRUE if the transform worked, ie both widgets share a parent and the transform between them is an invertible matrix.

`int gtk_widget_get_width(GtkWidget *widget)`  
`int gtk_widget_get_height(GtkWidget *widget)`  
We have those. They return the width/height of the content box.

`void gtk_widget_get_transformation_matrix(GtkWidget *widget, graphene_matrix_t *out_matrix)`  
Gets the transformation matrix from widget to its parent (for now that's just a 2d translation but that'll change later).
Not sure the name is great, but it needs to be reasonably different from the (more common) next function.

`gboolean gtk_widget_get_transform(GtkWidget *widget, GtkWidget *other_widget, graphene_matrix_t *out_matrix)`  
Gets the transform from other widget's coordinate system to widget's coordinate system.
Return value has same rules as gtk_widget_get_bounds().

events.target_title: Implement type-ahead find for efficient file system navigation
Implement type-ahead find for efficient file system navigation

note.body: The issue is that typing invokes a search, when all I want was to select the single file/folder that match what I am typing. For instance, consider that I want to open the folder "Anaconda3" from the current directory: Now, what I (and, arguably, a lot of users) are used to do, is to start typing "anaco" to select the folder: Instead, this is what I get: Rather than just selecting the single folder in a quick manner, the view changes into a list of search results. If I wanted to search for **any** file or folder matching "anaco", I'd invoke a search with CTRL+F.

events.target_title: Implement type-ahead find for efficient file system navigation

note.body:
Even though the file is selected, it took about 2 seconds for the search to initialize and find the file I was looking for. That's quite slow compared to the time I'd expect it to spend to just select the single file for me. I'd rather not have to sit and wait for 2 seconds for every folder I wish to enter.

And I don't want to view all the search matches there. Bottom line is, I didn't even want a search in the first place, just to select the single folder.

events.target_title: Implement type-ahead find for efficient file system navigation

note.body:
I realize what you're suggesting, I've given it a shot to try and efficiently navigate using the search feature, and it's a no-go for me.

The way file browsers will just instantly select a file/folder for me as I am typing is just so much better than initiating a search. I notice right away if the wrong file/folder is selected and smack ENTER as soon as it matches. It's incredibly efficient for navigating through my files. Initiating searches and listing all kinds of folders down the directory tree is just not what I want to happen while browsing my files.

events.target_title: Implement type-ahead find for efficient file system navigation

note.body:
In my personal opinion, it would be better to just **not** initiate searches this way (at least not by default).

My proposal is:

1. Remove automatically initiating a search by typing, searches are initiated by CTRL+F
2. Implement quick selection of file in current directory, matching user keyboard input

Add support for DDC/CI monitor control

note.body:
Yeah I know it does have some issues and might confuse people but if the feature is available I'd like to be able to use it (maybe the system could notify the user when a just plugged in display supports DDC).

But I absolutely agree with you on the fact that brightness control OLED panels has higher priority, this is a really annoying problem especially for people trying to use Wayland.

events.target_title: Design for Power panel

note.body:
I think a chart with power consumption over time would be the way to go.

Everybody understands what power consumption is and it's really easy to understand how things like watching videos or playing a game correlate with a higher power consumption (and also a higher fanspeed).

Another benefit of the daemon that is needed for this would be the ability to record cpu usage and make the power consumption graph interactive, so that hovering over it could show the programs utilizing the cpu at that time.

And for the question whether the stats should be shown when the device is plugged in: I think quite a few of the stats you want to show would be distorted. For example the power usage can't be measured while charging and some daemons might start cpu-heavy work (indexing, upgrading...) after being plugged in (which is actually a good thing). This might give the user a wrong perception of the battery draining apps and wouldn't honor the developers work to move cpu-heavy tasks to times when the device is plugged in. I would suggest to simply show the last discharging cycle while the device is charging.

events.target_title: Design for Power panel

note.body:
And why not only show the discharging cycles?  There would be quite a few issues if the charging is included in those stats (see my comment).

And by the way: Why would anybody care about this fancy battery charge line, it does not show any information of value to the user. Seriously, what could you learn from looking at this graph that you didn't know before? That you used your computer longer today than yesterday? Well (1.) you already know this and (2.) this does not have anything to do with power.

Please reconsider this design decision, I think the battery charge line is a really bad idea.

events.target_title: Wrong MIME Type When NFS Is Slightly Busy
Wrong MIME Type When NFS Is Slightly Busy

note.body: The NFS mount is asynchronously mounted over the kernel on a big server with hundreds of people running it at the same time.  This bug happens sometimes, but not often when the backup is not running on the NFS storage device.  When backups are running, this happens quite frequently.  Our support staff has been telling people to refresh the folder when this happens and the right mime type is then returned.  As mentioned, it takes about 2 seconds for the file to be fully saved when the drive is busy.

events.target_title: Wrong MIME Type When NFS Is Slightly Busy

note.body: Carlos, is this a won't fix?  We're still greatly affected by this, we get support calls about this issue a few times a week.  Nautilus refreshes prior to file being synced to the NFS drive and reports back flat file and offers Gedit.

events.target_title: Mutter does not notice failed mode set
Mutter does not notice failed mode set

note.body: I have not debugged it from user space, but I see that drm_crtc_helper_set_config() in the kernel, which is what calls us, ignores the error value we return (ENOMEM) with a simple boolean success/failure test and returns a generic -EINVAL.  I can verify this on Monday if you like (have to leave very shortly now).

events.target_title: qemu doesn't exit after using Boxes, uses lots of memory

note.body:
@felipeborges, in my case "Run in Background" is not ticked, yet QEMU continues running in the background indefinitely after closing the Boxes window. It doesn't suspend the VM as you'd expect.

I'm using the Boxes flatpak from flathub and running a Windows 10 VM. Automatic suspend on close definitely used to work for this setup at some point, I remember the massive 4GB disk write operation very clearly. Nowadays I have to terminate QEMU manually every time I close the Boxes window.

events.target_title: qemu doesn't exit after using Boxes, uses lots of memory

note.body:
@felipeborges, @aday, I've done some digging and found the culprit in my case, and possibly the reason this started happening in Boxes. It's not specific to flatpak. I'll explain my understanding of the issue as best I can.

My guess is that https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-boxes/commit/2e3553e0f752bae1ee759dc28c5e020c3c888417 introduced this issue for me, but I haven't verified this.

When using the CPU setting `host-passthrough` in QEMU like Boxes does, every detail/feature of the host CPU is exposed as-is to the guest machine. In my case, this includes VM nesting (running a VM inside a VM) since in Fedora 30 it appears to be enabled by default:
``` bash
[host ~]$ cat /sys/module/kvm_intel/parameters/nested
Y
```

In QEMU 3.1.0 (which is [the version packaged](https://github.com/flathub/org.gnome.Boxes/blob/bdcc216ad75e83ab8c4b3df3eba083f7ee7b75f0/org.gnome.Boxes.json#L393) in flathub's flatpak), CPU state migration isn't supported when the hypervisor is configured to allow nested VMX or SVM as highlighted by [this commit](https://github.com/qemu/qemu/commit/d98f26073bebddcd3da0ba1b86c3a34e840c0fb8). This is no longer the case in QEMU 4.1.0 since [this commit](https://github.com/qemu/qemu/commit/12604092e26cdace44c901bc429e7e4c7c3e0cab#diff-1b1540b1e56b33f6aea62589780fdf5e).

CPU state migration seems to be required for a few QEMU features, including snapshotting and saving (suspending to disk). When trying to save a VM using virsh, I got the error mentioned in the commit above:
``` bash
[📦 org.gnome.Boxes ~]$ virsh managedsave win10
error: Failed to save domain win10 state
error: internal error: unable to execute QEMU command 'migrate': Nested VMX virtualization does not support live migration yet
```
To work around this issue, I disabled the VMX feature for the guest CPU using `virsh edit`:
``` xml
<cpu mode='host-passthrough' check='none'>
  ...
  <feature name="vmx" policy="disable"/>
</cpu>
```
When running the VM with configuration, the `virsh managedsave` command succeeded and Boxes was able to save the VM to disk when it was closed and restore it later successfully.

However, it only worked as long as the same VM state was being saved and restored. It stopped working once the VM was rebooted because Boxes rewrites the CPU section every time with its own configuration and removes my changes, so VMX was re-enabled for new VM states.

So in theory there are a few ways to overcome this issue:
1.  Disable nested virtualization on the host. (not verified)
2.  Update to QEMU 4.1.0 and use a kernel version that supports the required IOCTLs to perform migration of nested VMs. (verified, see [flathub PR](https://github.com/flathub/org.gnome.Boxes/pull/30))
3.  Make Boxes disable VMX and SVM for its guest machines. (verified)

However, regardless of the above, Boxes should probably know how to gracefully handle such situations. Leaving QEMU running indefinitely when saving the VM to disk fails is not a good user experience.

dead accents keys should at least produce combining characters
dead accents keys should at least produce combining characters

note.body:
The feature was also requested on https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=341341 :

«
gtk/gtkimcontextsimple.h contains a table derived from en-US.UTF-8/Compose list.

However, it doesn't support deadkey combinations resolving to more than one Unicode character, which is needed for decomposed forms (especially when there are no precomposed forms, as is the case for Serbian Cyrillic).
»

which would be just solved completely without having to enumerate all decomposed forms used in Serbian if dead accents keys would just produce combining characters. That issue also shows how tired a user can become after having to add yet more support for his language in all pieces of the computer while it could just work already without having to specify anything:

«
Simos, there are none in en_US.UTF-8/Compose file because nobody bothered to add them or push for them. At one point, I simply lost time to chase all the things we've needed for Serbian (you can see that I am the author of Serbian GNU libc locale, Serbian XKB layouts, did many Serbian translations, worked on DejaVu Cyrillic... at one point you simply lose energy to chase all the maintainers around ;).
»

Defining combining keys is really a lame answer to the solution, it just makes people think "whoa, that Linux thing can't even support dead keys, it sucks, at least Windows supports them".

events.target_title: Wayland: gtk_window_set_geometry_hints causes unmaximizing to snap to off-by-one values
Wayland: gtk_window_set_geometry_hints causes unmaximizing to snap to off-by-one values

note.body:
When roxterm creates a window, before showing it, it packs all the widgets in, calls `gtk_widget_show_all()` on the immediate child of the top-level window and realizes the top-level; I think those steps are necessary to trigger size negotiation, so that I can work out the size of the "chrome" surrounding the VteTerminal widget to set the best window size to accommodate the desired terminal size.

Then it calls `gtk_window_set_geometry_hints()` on the top-level with a NULL geometry widget (non-NULL is deprecated since gtk 3.20) and a mask of `GDK_HINT_RESIZE_INC | GDK_HINT_BASE_SIZE | GDK_HINT_MIN_SIZE`. The `base_width` and `base_height` fields include padding in the Vte widget itself, the "chrome" (tab bar and menu bar if present) **and** the window decorations. I include the latter, because gnome-terminal does, and IIRC without it the window's initial size gets set smaller than desired.

After that I use the same terminal + chrome size etc (but this time **excluding** the top-level window decorations, otherwise it's too big) I calculated above and call `gtk_window_set_default_size()` on the top-level, then `gtk_window_present()`.

gnome-terminal works out and applies the geometry hints the same way as roxterm (basically I copied what they do), but it still uses `gtk_window_parse_geometry()` instead of `gtk_window_set_default_size()`. I changed roxterm because parse_geometry is deprecated.

events.target_title: Wayland: gtk_window_set_geometry_hints causes unmaximizing to snap to off-by-one values

note.body: See also [gnome-terminal bug #751064 on bugzilla](https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=751064), where I've described a [workaround](https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=751064#c13) and [Egmont Koblinger suggested](https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=751064#c9) it could be the responsibility of gnome-shell or Wayland.

Make jedi work even if not patched when installed.

note.body:
While the api changes concerned here: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-builder/issues/403 is handled in master I think, I am talking about the approach regarding jedi used by gnome-builder.

My primary concern is the wrong output `builder` gives. So, let me explain the scenario:

* I have gnome-builder installed currently 3.28 in ubuntu but it can be any version.
* I use latest `jedi` and obviously due to issue above builder will say `jedi not found` and nothing autocompletes.
* May be builder should say `gi.repository` patching not possible but generic python completion should work. This may save some speed as well such that documentation and girpath loading can be ignored.
* I have attached proof of concept above where I use additional variable named `IS_JEDI_PATCHED` and check for gi.repository object only when that is true.
* I am just wishing the 'all or nothing' regarding patching of `jedi` can be minimized.

events.target_title: Pylint extension

note.body:
@chergert I am not promising anything but I am thinking about working on some of the plugins that would make gnome-builder more appealing for python development.

The two things are:
*  pycodechecker plugin: Not just `pylint` but may be `pycodestyle`, `pyflake` or `flake8`. I am having hard time to grasp the arguments and return of `do_diagnose_async`. For python it may be unnecessary to spawn a process as we may be able to call API directly
* pyformatting plugin: I couldn't find anything on this but I see `Ide` api does have formatting. I would also like to know if there is a way to bind shortcuts from plugin for formatters to work.


I see builder does support `language-server-protocol` and these can be picked from available `language-server` plugin, the native support of python may make it faster and more controllable so just asking.

events.target_title: Automatic synchronization

note.body:
I've also realised that syncing works only in one direction: from gnome-todo to the nextcloud, but not the other way round. And not only are the remote tasks missing, this causes weird behaviour when remotely deleting a task that was created within gnome-todo: It will notice changes when launching the app before opening the list:

```
13:40:07.0225            GtdTaskListEds:    DEBUG: ECalClientView for tasklist 'Privat' successfully acquired
13:40:07.0250                GtdTaskRow:    DEBUG: Task changed
13:40:07.0256                GtdTaskRow:    DEBUG: Task changed
13:40:07.0262                GtdTaskRow:    DEBUG: Task changed
```

But the task is still displayed in the list. And when trying to manually delete or edit the task, the following error occurs shown since it does not exist on the server:

```
13:42:17.0374                GtdTaskRow:    DEBUG: Saving task…
13:42:17.0802            GtdProviderEds:  WARNING: An error occurred while modifying a task: Cannot modify calendar object: Failed to put data: HTTP error code 412 (Precondition failed): Sabre\DAV\Exception\PreconditionFailed
  An If-Match header was specified and the resource did not exist
  If-Match[exception][message][header]

```

This is why several people (including me) still get the error described in #121 despite the fix for #149.

events.target_title: Implement type-ahead find for efficient file system navigation

note.body:
@csoriano Thanks for taking this issue seriously. I will try to describe here the problems that I encounter with the new behavior so you might understand how to make it more user-friendly. 

1. I want to navigate the folder tree. I don't want to search. If I want to search I'll want to press Ctrl+F or similar to enter a search mode. I want my navigation mode to be navigation mode. 
2. Speed. Let's say I have a folder with 31 objects in there. I want to access with Enter something starting with "photographs". I start typing and hit Enter. Nothing happens because it hasn't done the search and it hasn't given focus to the folder. Even without the recursive search the folder-level search is too slow. The old type-ahead search worked instantly. 
3. Visual feedback. 
a) The above scenario. There's a small flicker, and a new toolbar appears and some of the folders disappear and all these things happen. I just want to access my folder with Enter. 
b) Disappearing folders. I don't want to see anything change in the folder viewport. With the search functionality folders that are not covered by the search disappear. I'm left with the few folders that I want to access. **It leaves me disoriented and distressed.** It would make more sense to just focus on the folder and leave other folders visible just like with the old type-ahead search. IDEA: Make it possible to disable the disappearing folders feature. This is perhaps the most annoying part of this new recursive search style. 
4. Disabling recursive search. The recursive search is not an issue because we can tick the box "never" for search in subfolders. I hope this checkbox remains there.

I hope this feedback helps you to deliver the best possible user experience Gnome can in the future.

events.target_title: Differentiate better between results in the current folder and other folders when searching

note.body: Some people like to search just at the top level of a directory. This functionality could help to make the view more understandable and less disorienting.

events.target_title: Differentiate better between results in the current folder and other folders when searching

note.body: That functionality is a good thing to be there and I like it. However, I'm referring to 3.b "Disappearing folders" in my post at #244.

events.target_title: Differentiate better between results in the current folder and other folders when searching

note.body: Thanks. Anything making the current thing more usable is welcome.

events.target_title: Implement type-ahead find for efficient file system navigation

note.body: @gerhardj explained nicely the feeling and confusion I get when using this new rexursive thing. @maxime.cheramy has the same workflow as I do, and it seems we have similar problems with the new recursive search.

events.target_title: Implement type-ahead find for efficient file system navigation

note.body:
> This is achieved filtering too, is it not? You put "a" and it will show apache logs if present. 

Filtering and changing focus are two different actions, I think. This focus thing is more about **visually exploring the folder view**. It's more about **jumping to a certain location** than trying to filter. Losing focus and seeing only filtered files causes this disorientation I talked about in my earlier message. @halka has a good analogy with tab completion and menu acceleration.

events.target_title: Initial setup: Allow connection to Other networks
Crash in icaltimezone_expand_changes

note.body:
I run into this crash several times per day when using the Activities overview. I press the Super key, quickly type the name of an app, and then immediately press Enter. 15% of the time I get the app I want but I also get a notification about this crash.

The crash goes away if I disable GNOME Calendar a search provider from Settings: Search.

I also get this “randomly”. Well, it’s not really random: I first get a notification from an unrelated app, and when that goes away I get a notification about this crash. Sometimes the whole desktop becomes unresponsive for two–three seconds before the crash notification appears.

The crash goes away if I disable GNOME Calendar a notification provider from Settings: Notifications.

Notably, I only open GNOME Calendar maybe once a week. I prefer to use Evolution (but I get a better overview of the week/month in Calendar so keep it around).

I’m subscribed to two WebCal calendars where one in UTC+1 and one in UTC, plus three CalDAV calendars (well one VTODO and two VCALENDARs) where two are UTC+1 and one is UTC.

events.target_title: Reader mode should run JS in isolated world, directly in web process, using custom URI scheme

note.body:
Here is an up-to-date comparison of the different URI schemes used by the different web browsers (really).
https://www.ctrl.blog/entry/browser-reading-view-uri

I recommend emulating Microsoft Edge’s ultra-clean `read:` URI.

Please also make sure to add the new protocol to the .desktop file and make the protocol accessible by external programs. That way, people can open things in reading mode from other applications (like a feed reader or read-it-later list program) by prefixing the reading-mode URI.

events.target_title: Build extensions with shared_module instead of shared_library
Build extensions with shared_module instead of shared_library

note.body: There are differences between shared_library() and shared_module() on some platforms.  For instance, on Cygwin (and Windows), using the former creates and installs an import library, where the latter does not.  An import library obviously does not make sense with a loadable extension, as it is not meant to be linked against.

Solution for Type=Link .desktop files?

note.body:
Link (type 2) desktop files cannot be replaced by bookmarks on the sidebar or by symbolic links because the URL field can be *any* kind of URL, including `sftp://`, `https://`, `file://`, `irc://`, and `mailto:` URLs.

Clicking on a Link type desktop file doesn't merely navigate to a location within Nautilus, it opens the URL with *whatever application is registered to handle that URL scheme*, such as a web browser for `https://` URLs.

Here's an example of how I use this: I collect the files for a bug report in a directory somewhere, then file a bug report online. Next [I drag and drop from the address bar of my favorite web browser into Nautilus](https://mail.gnome.org/archives/nautilus-list/2005-January/msg00051.html) to create a desktop file in the relevant directory pointing to the page where the bug report lives. Now I can navigate to this directory in Nautilus later and easily open that page in my web browser. The desktop file is local to that directory, so I can actually find it later, rather than attempting to sift through global browser bookmarks or Nautilus sidebar bookmarks.

I understand that there is a maintenance cost to supporting desktop files, but please give this issue further consideration before [permanently removing support for all desktop files](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/nautilus/issues/184). They're not only [useful](https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=720390), they're also a Free Desktop standard, first published in [February 2007](https://specifications.freedesktop.org/desktop-entry-spec/desktop-entry-spec-1.0.xml) and updated December 2017.

https://developer.gnome.org/desktop-entry-spec/

https://standards.freedesktop.org/desktop-entry-spec/desktop-entry-spec-latest.html

events.target_title: Solution for Type=Link .desktop files?

note.body:
Quoting Carlos Soriano ( @csoriano ):

> Also, where did you see this is a standard for file managers? In neither of the freedesktop spec or the gnome developer site it's mentioned a file manager. This spec is intended for menus, an application launcher, etc. In any case, this is an implementation detail that shouldn't matter for users.

I don't agree, since *both* sites mention the exact phrase "file manager" multiple times.

> Icon to display in file manager, menus, etc.

> A number of special field codes have been defined which will be expanded by the file manager or program launcher when encountered in the command line.

The standard even explicitly mentions the `NoDisplay` key is for launching things like URLs *without* a menu entry.

> `NoDisplay` means "this application exists, but don't display it in the menus". This can be useful to e.g. associate this application with MIME types, so that it gets launched from a file manager (or other apps), without having a menu entry for it (there are tons of good reasons for this, including e.g. the `netscape -remote`, or `kfmclient openURL` kind of stuff).

When I double-click on a file, Nautilus launches an application by URI via its `nautilus_launch_default_for_uri_async` function:

Could you expand on what the primary obstacles are for Link type desktop support in Nautilus?

events.target_title: Solution for Type=Link .desktop files?

note.body:
Here is an example use case of a `file://` URL
and why I find it is necessary to use a Link type desktop file.

Say I have a stack trace from a [core dump of Nautilus](https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=861989)
in this directory:

    ~/Dropbox/2018/bugs/nautilus/2018-04-10/

but then I find out that
[this bug isn't in Nautilus](https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=783869),
it's in a different package, the tracker tags plugin for Nautilus,
and suppose that's already listed in a different directory, e.g.

    ~/Dropbox/2017/bugs/tracker-gui/2017-10-05/

So I want to be able to jump to that older directory
from the newer directory.

One way way to do this is with a Nautilus bookmark.
But this isn't significant enough to warrant it's own bookmark;
I only want to be able to jump there from
`~/Dropbox/2018/bugs/nautilus/2018-04-10/`,
not from everywhere.
(Here's another limitation of Nautilus bookmarks:
[they can point to directories, but not to files](https://askubuntu.com/questions/803644/how-can-i-pin-a-file-to-the-bookmarks).)

Well, the next possibility is to use a symbolic link.
Something like this:

    $ ln -s ~/Dropbox/2017/bugs/tracker-gui/2017-10-05/ ~/Dropbox/2018/bugs/nautilus/2018-04-10/link-to-tracker-gui-bug

However, there are two problems with this.
Firstly, file syncing clients for services like [Dropbox](https://www.dropbox.com/) and [Insync](https://www.insynchq.com/)
[do not handle symbolic links well](http://www.paulingraham.com/dropbox-and-symlinks.html),
especially links internal to the synced folder.
I've come perilously close to permanently losing data
by attempting to store internal links in my Dropbox folder.

Secondly, [symbolic links have different semantics from shortcuts or hyperlinks](https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=702301).
If I follow that link above, my working directory looks like this:

    ~/Dropbox/2018/bugs/nautilus/2018-04-10/link-to-tracker-gui-bug/

Not like this:

    ~/Dropbox/2017/bugs/tracker-gui/2017-10-05/

On the command line, it's simple enough to use [`realpath`](https://www.gnu.org/software/coreutils/manual/html_node/realpath-invocation.html)
to figure out where the current directory *actually* is,
but [doing this in Nautilus is non-trivial](https://askubuntu.com/questions/720491/nautilus-visited-directory-via-symlink-now-i-cant-go-one-level-up-in-the-targ).
(By the way, symlinks are tricky, and handling them improperly has caused a [number](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2002-0157) of [security issues](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2009-3289) in Nautilus. But that doesn't mean Nautilus should abandon support for symbolic links.)

So instead I use a desktop file; it looks something like this:

    $ pwd
    /home/nathaniel/Dropbox/2018/bugs/nautilus/2018-04-10/
    $ cat link-to-tracker-gui-bug.desktop
    [Desktop Entry]
    Name=Link to tracker-gui bug
    Type=Link
    URL=file:///home/nathaniel/Dropbox/2017/bugs/tracker-gui/2017-10-05/
    Icon=folder

This ability to *hyperlink* the filesystem like a wiki
is useful for all kinds of things:

- I can use it in 2018/tax-filing to jump to 2017's tax documents.

- I can use it for jumping to photos and video projects that are outside of Dropbox
  because of storage quota limitations.

- I can use it to link in and out of shared Dropbox folders.

- And any other time I want navigate the file manager to a specific directory
  without having to copy and paste into the address bar.

Since Nautilus is the registered application for `file://` scheme support,
this can't be farmed out to the terminal or the web browser.

I'm not the only one who uses this functionality.
In fact, Ubuntu's `example-content` package features a Link type desktop file pointing to `file:///usr/share/example-content/`:

https://bazaar.launchpad.net/~ubuntu-art-pkg/example-content/trunk/view/head:/data/examples.desktop.in

There are plenty of other examples of users who have `file://` links in their Link type desktop files.

http://forums.debian.net/viewtopic.php?t=64048

https://askubuntu.com/questions/214908/cross-system-file-links

https://askubuntu.com/questions/2484/what-does-examples-desktop-do

https://askubuntu.com/questions/279332/how-can-i-remove-the-gray-boxes-around-custom-folder-icons/287195#287195

https://askubuntu.com/questions/289706/how-can-i-assign-custom-icons-to-folders-persistently

https://askubuntu.com/questions/596655/file-shortcut-to-a-dash-home-entry

https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=237986

https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=836767

https://github.com/JeffHoogland/moksha/blob/af00fb95719ebd8691722af12e19b440d246c73a/data/favorites/tmp.desktop

https://github.com/mate-desktop/mate-panel/issues/590

https://github.com/trueos/trueos-docs/blob/a592d6209d34740d01a4fa20d9b8cd85f9e400c5/trueos-handbook/xtrafiles/handbook.desktop

note.body:
The issue is reproducible with gtk3-demo

* Download the official gedit installer from http://ftp.gnome.org/pub/GNOME/binaries/win64/gedit/gedit-x86_64-3.20.1.msi
* Download the Adapta Gtk theme from the official Arch Linux package https://www.archlinux.org/packages/community/any/adapta-gtk-theme/ (from that page you can 'Download From Mirror')
* Extract the tarball and place the theme in gedit\share\themes
* Edit gedit\etc\gtk-3.0\settings.ini. Add the line
 'gtk-theme-name=Adapta'

And you're done.
To monitor resources you can use process explorer https://download.sysinternals.com/files/ProcessExplorer.zip
Be sure to select View - Select Columns - Process Memory - GDI objects
Now launch gedit and tinker with the UI. opening many tabs and closing them triggers the problem. Even opening / closing the about dialog. The situation is more problematic with gtk3-demo (not included in gedit installation) with combo box and treeview examples

note.body:
I've tried to reproduce it in a reasonably fresh gtk-3-22, and i guess there's something to that.
When using Vimix theme (by the way, i couldn't get it to work 100% correctly - it was failing to load images for check/radio marks and maybe something else, but did load window decoration button images just fine) i would get steady GDI handles increase, but i did have to practically click on *every* widget in widget-factory, multiple times (just clicking on the same widget over an over doesn't cut it - you need to twiddle around with all of them). Eventually i reached 10000 handles, and the program promptly crashed.

With the default Adwaita theme i couldn't break the 800 handles barrier, no matter what i was doing. Using a custom version of Adwaita that i had laying around (basically - Adwaita with a few bits removed), i couldn't make it crash either. So there's definitely something to do with the theme.

events.target_title: Arrow keys do not allow to navigate after typing a few letters

note.body:
Looks like this ticket is related: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/nautilus/issues/133

However, while the suggested solution would probably satisfy most of my needs, this behavior looks a bit strange to me.

Instead, my suggestion is the following:
- entered characters (including backspace) should update the search entry without changing the focus
- focus could still be changed manually as any graphical component (e.g. by clicking on it).

I just re-installed gnome-todo since I can now use it with Todoist. I'm not sure if this is what OP meant, but I'd love to see global key shortcuts or at least command-line APIs to be able to write arbitrary scripts and create shortcuts.

The main types of activities I'd love to be able to do through global shortcuts are:
*  create a new task on an arbitrary list
*  pull up the 'Today' view
*  pull up the 'Scheduled' view
*  pull up the view for an arbitrary list

I already have a browser open most of the time, so if I have to open an application to create a task I might as well just switch to that tab. I'd love to just be able to hit a keyboard shortcut in any context, type out my task (which in my case would just be added to my Todoist inbox) and go on with my day. The main goal here is to follow the GTD methodology by easily offloading things as I remember them.

note.body:
Can I request that "`.desktop` file support" be considered for inclusion somewhere on that list, at least for `Type=Link` pointers to folders?

In theory they could be replaced with symlinks to the folder, but Nautilus has always treated `.desktop` files differently from symlinks. The directory `/home/$USER/Videos` and a symlink to it at `/home/$USER/Desktop/Videos` are treated as two different folders in Nautilus. (In terms of thumbnailing, Recents, breadcrumbs, etc.) But if `/home/$USER/Desktop/Videos.desktop` is a `Type=Link` pointer to `URL=file:///home/$USER/Videos/`, Nautilus knows it's the same folder no matter which way you access it.

note.body:
This was one of the (many) issues with Nautilus' built-in desktop icon support, but with that support removed in 3.28 obviously it won't still be an issue in Nautilus. And this new desktop icon feature is a Gnome Shell extension, not part of Nautilus at all, so there's no reason that bug would be carried over to the extension. (Indeed, at current the extension doesn't support changing the icon size; it's hardcoded at `64px`.)

I'd say that Ubuntu bug could be closed with a message like "desktop icons feature removed from Nautilus". It's not going to be fixed, because that code is gone.

events.target_title: Solution for Type=Link .desktop files?
Nautilus icon view grows content pane far longer than needed to hold folder contents
Apply changes instead of canceling when dismissing rename popup

note.body:
The tricky thing about this is comes down to both the implicit action's visibility and reversibility.

* Reversibility is something of a concern only because Nautilus has just a single undo level. If you unintentionally rename something, you _can_ undo it, but **only** if you catch it immediately. If you take any other action following that rename (**ETA:** Any _undoable_ action, not simple actions like navigation or opening a file), the ability to undo that rename is gone forever. An implicit rename would be less potentially dangerous if the very next action taken didn't wipe out any hope of reversing it.

* Visibility, though, seems like a much bigger concern. Currently when you rename something, Nautilus sorts it into its new position, scrolls that position into view (if necessary), and leaves the item selected under its new name. All of that's good, and makes it easy to notice that you've actually performed a rename. 

    But when the user clicks outside the popup, presumably they may be clicking on a different icon, in which case they probably want to interact with that icon.

    Currently Nautilus will dismiss the popup, no changes will be made to the folder contents, and the selection will remain on the original file (the one being renamed). The user can then click a second time to select whatever icon their pointer was positioned over.

    If the rename popup's action is changed to auto-apply, though, then it seems to me there's an uncomfortable choice between either scrolling the view to show the results of the rename operation (moving the intended recipient of the click out from under the user's pointer), or **not** showing the results of an implicitly-applied rename operation if the rename causes the icon to be moved out of view, which makes it much more likely that the user might be unaware that they accidentally renamed something.

events.target_title: Only add "Show Details" to context menus of apps GNOME Software knows about

note.body:
> Section _Installing a Thumbnailer Program_ at https://developer.gnome.org/integration-guide/stable/thumbnailer.html.en documents about path '/desktop/gnome/thumbnailers/' which **does not exist on Fedora systems**. At best /usr/share/ does exist on the system.

That documentation is _incredibly_ out of date (it's for Gnome 2), and no longer applies to Gnome 3 / Gnome Shell as thumbnail generation and management has been completely redesigned. (Those `/desktop/gnome/thumbnailers/` strings aren't filesystem paths, but rather keys from the old GConf system which is no longer in use. Thumbnail definitions _have_ been moved to the filesystem, as files placed in `/usr/share/thumbnailers/`.)

The **current** documentation that you want to be working off _should_ be located here: ~~https://developer.gnome.org/gnome-desktop3/stable/GnomeDesktopThumbnailFactory.html~~

However, there isn't actually any content at that URL, because it appears that whatever process exports GTK API docs to the website is broken. So, the documentation that's intended to be available at its canonical location... is unfortunately missing.

You can find a mirror of the content that's supposed to be on that page here, though: http://www.manpagez.com/html/gnome-desktop3/gnome-desktop3-3.24.2/GnomeDesktopThumbnailFactory.php (The mirror's slightly out of date, but **nothing** has changed regarding thumbnailing since Gnome 3.24.)

And this blog post about writing `.thumbnailer` files can also serve as a helpful guide: https://tecnocode.co.uk/2013/10/21/writing-a-gnome-thumbnailer/

events.target_title: ENOENTs when running thumbnail helper under bubblewrap

note.body:
I've been having some issues with the wrapped thumbnailers as well, in my case with a python-based thumbnailer that doesn't like running in the bubblewrap sandbox — it ends up setting off SELinux alerts when it tries to run `ldconfig`!, of all things, for reasons that are not yet clear to me. (But I think maybe I'm glad that gets blocked.)

However, since I have very little concrete information about what the bwrap environment looks like for the thumbnailers running in it (and since I noticed that all of the _working_ ones distributed by Gnome and/or Fedora happen to be binary thumbnailers), I ended up putting together an experiment to test the usability of bash-script thumbnailers. And based on the results, I can say that shell scripts definitely do work as thumbnailers even in the new sandboxed environment.

Here's what I did:

1. In my case I was testing `.cbr` (comic-book rar archive) thumbnailing, after Evince in Fedora 28 inexplicably lost that ability for me in a recent update. So, I grabbed a typical file and generated a `thumbnail.png` by hand using the working (but non-operational in bwrap) Python thumbnailer.

1. I wanted to test using a self-contained shell script with as few external dependencies as possible. (The final result ended up only needing to be able to run `mimencode`.) So I decided to embed `thumbnail.png` directly into the script, instead of having it try to read the image from disk. A quick trip to the MIME toolset fixed me up:
   ```sh
   mimencode -q thumbnail.png > cbrthumb.sh
   ```

1. That got me a file containing a quoted-printable encoding of my thumbnail image, which I wrapped into a shell script as a HERE-doc.

1. By running the image data back through `mimencode` in reverse and saving it to the output location on the command line, my script could emulate a thumbnailer. When run it accepts the standard set of thumbnailer arguments, writes that same image to the path given for the thumbnail output file, and just ignores all the rest of the arguments:
   ```sh
   #!/bin/sh
   mimencode -q -u -o "$2" <<"__HERE__"
   # XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX
   # Quoted-printable image data here
   # XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX
   __HERE__
   ```
   ...And that was it, that was my entire "thumbnailer". 

1. I installed the script into `/usr/bin/`, set it executable, and gave it the proper context with `sudo chcon -t thumb_exec_t /usr/bin/cbrthumb.sh`. 

1. Then I created the thumbnailer file `/usr/share/thumbnailers/cbrthumb.thumbnailer`:
```desktop
[Thumbnailer Entry]
TryExec=cbrthumb.sh
Exec=cbrthumb.sh %u %o %s
MimeType=application/x-cb7;application/x-cbr;application/x-cbt;application/x-cbz;application/x-ext-cb7;application/x-ext-cbr;application/x-ext-cbt;application/x-ext-cbz;application/vnd.comicbook+zip;application/vnd.comicbook-rar;
```

...And to my fairly great surprise, to be honest, _that **worked**_. My system started thumbnailing every `.cbr` and `.cbz` file with that same image I embedded into my script.

So, shell scripts definitely _are_ able to run within bwrap, and presumably so could Python programs and other non-binary-format thumbnailers as well. As long as they're well-behaved and conservatively coded, so they don't end up trying to do things like run `ldconfig` from within the sandbox.

events.target_title: Only add "Show Details" to context menus of apps GNOME Software knows about

note.body:
Oh, @Ricky\-Tigg — I neglected to mention: this...

> - **No application entry was created** along with the creation of the menu integration associated to the presently added application:
>
> ![Nautilus_Properties_Open-with](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/uploads/1930f0d47383a4d4dd09d1f8fe3b9d1e/Nautilus_Properties_Open-with.png)

is because file-type associations are only available for applications that list themselves as handling the `MimeType` of the file in question. Your desktop entry contains the line:
```desktop
MimeType=image/png
```
which means that Waterfox will only be available as an application to open PNG images. You'd likely want something like this in the desktop file (from `/usr/share/applications/firefox.desktop` on Fedora):
```desktop
MimeType=text/html;text/xml;application/xhtml+xml;application/vnd.mozilla.xul+xml;
text/mml;x-scheme-handler/http;x-scheme-handler/https;
```
(You can also include `image/png` if you want to be able to associate Waterfox with PNG images.) But the `MimeType=` list should really end in a semicolon to indicate that it's a list, even if it's only one item long. If you were to try to run `desktop-file-edit --add-mime-type=text/html /usr/share/applications/waterfox.desktop` on your file as it exists above, you'd get an error:
```
waterfox.desktop: error: (will be fatal in the future): value "image/pngtext/html;" for key
"MimeType" in group "Desktop Entry" contains value "image/pngtext/html" which is an invalid
MIME type: "image/pngtext/html" contains an invalid character in the subtype
```
See the [freedesktop Desktop Entry Specification](https://standards.freedesktop.org/desktop-entry-spec/latest/index.html) for details.

note.body:
The dependencies and the required versions of them is defined in the configure.ac file. Using grep and sed I came up with the following line that extracts the dependency information and presents it as a list:
   grep ^m4_define configure.ac | grep _version | sed -r 's/\w+..(\w+)], .([\.0-9]+)../\1, \2/' | grep -v 'gimp'

NOTE: The above line has only been tested under Linux.

@vanvugt Do we know what exactly is causing frames to drop upon loading of the textures? Personally, I think it is related to a resource "bandwidth" problem. I have found that the "spring" animation is buttery smooth when only loading 12 icons or so, but the more icons present in app grid will cause frame drops. Also, having any other application open, let alone a resource-intensive one, will make things less fluid. Occasionally, it will skip almost every frame. 

Upon browsing the GNOME shell source tree, I can see that there is a caching mechanism. Any thoughts?

events.target_title: "Loading" text does not disappear after switching Artists tab
We need more shared runners

note.body:
Speaking to @vielmetti on Packet's community Slack, he said they had received a couple of requests from GNOME and related projects like freedesktop-sdk already, such as https://github.com/WorksOnArm/cluster/issues/33 and https://github.com/WorksOnArm/cluster/issues/44.

Ideal for them would be if someone at GNOME (and freedesktop-sdk) could put together one ask for what we could use in total. Even though the freedesktop-sdk is on Gitlab.org, my rudimentary cloud understanding suggests that if we have one orchestrator for spinning up Packet instances with some other containers on (Docker, Kubernetes, whatever) we could make that available as a pool of CI workers to both Gitlabs.

Seems we have some AWS workers ready to go, but my experience is that a dedicated Packet instance will be heaps faster - and as Ed suggests if we're testing across both ARM and Intel we could also reasonably request some Intel infra from Packet. They have Type 2A2 instances, which are HiSilicon 64-core ARM servers which are able to run both 32-bit and 64-bit ARM instructions, which will let us test across all 4 of {Intel,ARM} {32,64}-bit.

events.target_title: We need more shared runners

note.body:
> But of course ARM runners (and more x86 ones) are more than welcomed. @ramcq is right we only need one coordinator in each instance/project and we will be able to share the infra. Or we can split the server in several vm and split the resources

VMs? That's not very "bare metal" of you... :) I'm sure provided we have a container orchestrator of some sort running, we can arrange credentials for both projects to start workers, so that we don't need to duplicate the "plumbing" between the two. After all, the end goal of Gitlab CI workers is also to sandbox/etc the work being done, so no point introducing an additional layer if we don't need it.

events.target_title: We need more shared runners

note.body:
I had another chat with @vielmetti and he clarified - we don't need to actually share instances if it's a pain for us organizationally - it was more like, these are similar requests, so if we work together to get one working recipe for "here's a thing that gets you Gitlab CI workers on Packet instances" then we can use it across GNOME and fd.o SDK already, and he can also point other would-be Packet Gitlab CI-ers to it too.

They also have some ARM "Type 2A" boxes with 32GB RAM rather than 128GB RAM which have been earmarked for this kind of build/CI usage, so we could make use of those.

events.target_title: Boxes should be available as a flatpak

note.body:
Hi @felipeborges - I don't think your approach is quite right right one - to say that a Flatpak isn't possible just because of USB redirection or whatever. Obviously as the developer these features are newer/shinier and more recent and have taken more of your time - but Pareto principle suggests that actually, 80% of your users could be happy with more restricted functionality.

What I was trying to do with the first Flatpak was just to allow Boxes to be a libvirt (spice, etc) client rather than handle all of the virtualisation problems - so I just stubbed all of that code. The next step would then be to figure out the most basic virtualisation, taking an image file rather than a block device (avoiding host udev/osinfo dependencies) etc.

With a working Flatpak build, even if it was slightly restricted, you could improve access for testers and users, and then iterate to unlock extra functionality (or even get contributions for that - Flathub is great for this!). Also - I think a lot of these features /are/ possible, we just need to work through one by one to figure out the right approach to access them within the sandbox. But the motivation to do that is very low if nothing is possible at the moment.

If you can spend some time on this to navigate me through the Boxes codebase and help debugging failures, I'd love to work with you on the Flatpak and getting a working MVP up and running.

events.target_title: Boxes should be available as a flatpak

note.body: @felipeborges Ah! OK, makes sense. :) Let me update the flatpak I have to 3.28 and we can see how it looks.

events.target_title: Change license to GPLv3 so we can depend on FreeRDP

note.body: I think what @teuf means is that there is no permission necessary to relicense everything in Boxes from LGPLv2.1 to LGPLv3 because the headers are LGPLv2.1+ (ie - or at your option a later version). So anybody (me included) can take a copy of Boxes, place an LGPLv3 license on it, and start to link with Apache licensed stuff.

events.target_title: Change license to GPLv3 so we can depend on FreeRDP

note.body:
Strictly speaking, the license is not compatible. The files have been granted multiple licenses, LGPL v2.1 which is not, and later versions (such as 3) which could be. Saying "yes it's compatible" is is a little sneaky IMO because the code you have which is apparently marked as LGPL v2.1 can't really be used with that license when it links to FreeRDP. Someone building the combined thing must behave as it was LGPLv3 licensed, otherwise they are acting under bad information.

So - if FreeRDP becomes a mandatory dependency, it's clearer to just update your top-level license to LGPLv3+ and use that for new files and those that link FreeRDP. If it's an optional dependency, you could consider some kind of --enable-lgpl3  which would be required to be explicitly specified in order to "unlock" FreeRDP (and any other GPLv3 dependencies), so that the user knows what they have is not LGPLv2.1 any more.

note.body:
Hi Timm,

Thanks for the thoughts! Yes, if `for_size != -1`, the text would presumably need to be rewrapped in a new layout. But that doesn't happen in the test case, nor in the real app (Balsa e-mail client). Documentation in gtklabel.c suggests that `for_size == -1` means infinite, which must be OK for `GtkLabel` but would be a disaster for `GtkTextView`! Returning the current layout height for the current layout width seems to be what callers expect, at least `GtkScrolledWindow`.

Glad to see that the patch doesn't re-introduce your bug! Your fix removed some weird issues with text-views resizing themselves in scrolled windows, so I was really happy to see it.

note.body:
Yes, that has the same behaviour:

`$ touch baz
$ ls -l --full-time baz 
-rw-r--r-- 1 user user 0 2018-02-21 08:30:38.527791882 +0000 baz
$ gio copy baz xyzzy
$ ls -l --full-time xyzzy
-rw-r--r-- 1 user user 0 2018-02-21 08:30:38.527791000 +0000 xyzzy`

`gio info` displays timestamps as a tuple of {seconds since the epoch,microseconds}, so it looks like a bug in gio. Classic example of reinventing the wheel.

Where do we go from here?

gio-2.0: mark ActionEntry parameter_type and state fields as nullable

note.body:
Hi @ricotz,

Thanks for updating the fields so they are marked nullable. I still don't understand why `weak` has been used instead of `unowned`. Looks like you've changed it back to `weak` in staging.

From https://wiki.gnome.org/Projects/Vala/ReferenceHandling

> Currently many types in the Vala binding APIs are falsely marked weak even though they should actually be unowned. This is because in the past there was only the weak keyword for both, so don't let this confuse you. At the moment weak and unowned can be used interchangeably.
> However, you should use weak only for breaking reference cycles and unowned only for ownership issues as described obove.
