events.target_title: Disabling night light should disable it till sunrise, not till midnight

note.body:
I stand by what I said in the original bug report
https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=778767#c11

The "disable until sunrise" feature is too complex and has a lot of edge cases. What if there is no sunrise tomorrow (addressed in the proposed patch I know, but still, that's added complexity) ? What if I set night light to manual, from 10PM to 10AM and sunrise is at 9AM, will night light reactivate from 9AM to 10AM? That sounds silly so the feature should become "disable until sunrise or next schedule".

Again, I think one would be very wrong to assume they know the the users location accurately enough at high latitudes to be able to calculate the time of sunrise with even a few hours of precision.

I would really go for simplicity here and just have a "disable for Xh" feature, with said Xh being settable in GSettings.

events.target_title: Disabling night light should disable it till sunrise, not till midnight

note.body:
@nirbheek Do you disagree with this statement:
>  I think one would be very wrong to assume they know the the users location accurately enough at high latitudes to be able to calculate the time of sunrise with even a few hours of precision.

If you do, please explain.

From the previous bug report:
>  At "high latitudes", GeoClue (or whatever trick one uses to estimate a user's coordinates) is pretty much clue-less because communities living there are most likely using a satellite link and will be geo-located somewhere else. Also, there is usually no way to properly set the time-zone in a way that makes sense with the natural daylight cycle (many research stations in Antarctica will use UTC or the timezone of their country of origin for scientific or logistical convenience).

>  Therefore, whatever you try to do automatically at these latitudes will most likely result in an undesired behaviour.

And it's not just Antarctica, people in the North of Norway or Canada for example will be geolocated in cities many hundred miles South of their actual positions and that makes the sunrise calculations way off.

So my line of reasoning is "we have no way of knowing the user's location precisely enough for a whole category of users. As a result, you can fix as many bugs as you want, trying to do clever things with the wrong data will result in a worse behaviour than something simple and stupid."

Also, if one wants to "improve the workflow for as many people as possible", maybe we should try to figure out why people want to disable night light in the first place. I have a feeling that it's because they're either watching a film or showing a presentation. Maybe it would be better to have an option to automatically disable night light when an application goes full screen (like a video player) or let the said applications disable night light themselves.

events.target_title: Disabling night light should disable it till sunrise, not till midnight

note.body:
And if "people living in high latitudes" seems too niche, I also have problems with GeoClue when:
*  Using a wireless / lte connection (especially when roaming)
*  Using a VPN as a secondary automatic connection in NetworkManager (the probe goes via the VPN)
*  On a long flight

To the point that I have even disabled automatic timezone...

note.body: Is there a plan to replace this feature with a better implementation? Without it, it appears to be impossible to get a GTK widget into a non-XDG shell surface. This will inhibit GTK being used for desktop shell components. In particular, it will block [GTK Layer Shell](https://github.com/wmww/gtk-layer-shell)  getting ported to GTK 4, and by extension, MATE's work-in-progress Wayland support that is using it. Let me know what needs to get implemented to bring this (or equivalent) back.

events.target_title: Drop gdk_wayland_surface_set_use_custom_surface

note.body:
Oops, wasn't getting notifications.

> The most obvious idea would be to introduce a `GdkWaylandSurfaceRole` class that GTK itself implements for xdg-shell toplevels & popups, and apps could implement for themselves on top of layer-shell or another protocol.

This sounds like the best idea to me. It would also allow all the shells (XDG stable, V6, V5 and Wl) to coexist cleanly.

I agree discussion is better in IRC, I'll get notifications if someone mentions `wmww`.

I don't have a huge amount of time to dedicate (MATE is an offshoot of my main thing, and patching GTK is an offshoot of MATE), but I'd be happy to help out where I can. Not a big fan of extended debate, so I'll generally stay out of the way. Please let me know if something is decided on and needs to be implemented.

events.target_title: GTK4 and Wayland shells

note.body:
My current favorite idea is a `GdkWaylandShellSurface` class that is implemented internally by `GdkXdgShellSurface`, and can also be implemented by users. `GdkWaylandSurface` can then call into it and doesn't have to care about the implementation details of the shell surface. This would simplify gdksurface-wayland.c, allow implementing as many shell protocols as desired (XDG V6, XDG V5, WL, etc) and allow those implementations to either live in GTK or in 3rd party libraries.

I'm hoping to have a chance to hack on this next week, and pull a prototype together.

__matthiasc:__ Yes, but that forces us to make a lot of promises in the Wayland backend about interactions with this external implementation that we may not want to make.

RFC: Integrating rsvg-rs into librsvg

note.body:
Hi everyone. I currently don't have a lot of time to spend, but I will try to help as much as possible with the move (and maybe further maintenance) of `rsvg-rs`.

The thing I can give the most input about is `rsvg-rs`, so I will start with that.

There is currently only a single GIR file used that I got from some Debian package as I stated [here](https://github.com/gtk-rs/gir-files/pull/7). Looking at the [current code](https://github.com/selaux/rsvg-rs/blob/master/Makefile), it actually seems to use `Gtk-3.0.gir` for that. I'm not sure if that is correct, if I forgot to commit something there or if I just dont understand my code correctly. I have to double check.

Publishing an updated `rsvg-rs` should not be an issue. Basically it's version is independent of the librsvg version and can be published independently to `crates.io` using `cargo publish`. I'm not yet sure how to handle updates to the GIR file though (how frequent are they anyways?).

[Documentation](https://docs.rs/rsvg/0.3.0/rsvg/) is based on comments in Rust. So it is mostly empty, as gir does not actually create comments for documentation. As far as I can see, the only reliable way currently is to add them manually. This seems like a lot of work to me, and they will be removed on regeneration of the bindings.

This is what currently should to be done each time a new version of `gtk-rs` has been released in order to ensure compatibility with applications that use that version of `gtk-rs`.

note.body:
Thank you for your attention to my request, Antonio.  It seems a shame to eliminate desktop icons entirely, yet I'm certain your team must have a better solution for vision impaired users.  I presume you are telling the rest of us who have developed workflows, styles and years of experience to move on?  

The desktop icon metaphor dates back to early development at Xerox' Palo Alto Laboratory, where thousands of man-hours were invested to make the computer accessible to normal humans.  It was later adopted by the Apple Lisa, and the rest is history.

I will anxiously wait to see what new and revolutionary visual man-machine interface your team has created.

Regards,
Dennis

Get rid of the `get_value_from_model` method
Get rid of the `get_value_from_model` method

note.body:
Formatting values works for frame rates and audio rates but there seems to be no simple way for formatting [audio channels](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/pitivi/blob/master/pitivi/utils/ui.py#L613) or [aspect ratios](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/pitivi/blob/master/pitivi/utils/ui.py#L621) without the function turning into a lookup table itself.

I guess we could standardize output Eg. "2 Audio Channels" instead of "Stereo" but this would lead to inconsistencies with other UI like the Project Settings window which use the models directly.

Implementing a function on top of these models would also simplify future updates. Eg. just adding `(_("8 Channels (7.1)"), 8)` to audio_channels would add it as a option to the project settings, render dialog and show it as such in clip properties.

The idea is to use the model's values when available and only format those which are missing.

events.target_title: Cannot redo title clip addition

note.body:
I think the bug is in **GList * ges_layer_get_clips_in_interval (GESLayer * layer, GstClockTime start, GstClockTime end)** function. When we create a GList of intersecting clips, we directly insert the GESTimelineElement objects (rather than inserting their reference), but when we free up the GList we use **gst_object_unref** on every GList element's data, i.e., we decrement their reference count by 1. After 2 or 3 such calls, the reference count gets decremented to zero and the GESTimelineElment object is destroyed. Now when we try to access this object in Pitivi, we get a segfault and Pitivi crashes.

A solution to this is to insert the reference of GESTimeline object in the GList. Something like this - 

`if (clip_intersects)
      intersecting_clips =
          g_list_insert_sorted (intersecting_clips,
          gst_object_ref (tmp->data), (GCompareFunc) element_start_compare);`

events.target_title: Making link from Nautilus doesn't use the correct working directory

note.body:
Apologies, I copypasted what the Ubuntu reporter had wrote.
I think what they're trying to say (and I can reproduce this) is that if you make a link and move it to another folder, when you open that link it will say that the file is 'Link to x' in the new folder, not just file 'x' in the old folder. E.g. I make the file 'test' using Text Editor, save to ~, create 'Link to Test', move it to Documents, and open the file. Text Editor says that the file I'm editing is 'Link to Test' in ~/Documents rather than 'Test' in ~. Perhaps this is intentional? In which case you can close this bug and I'll ask for the Ubuntu one to be closed, but this does seem like a bug to me.

events.target_title: Switching to certain non-latin keyboard layouts disables (at least) the Insert key on GNOME 3.32 & Xorg

note.body:
I confirm this bug in Fedora 30 Beta.

And I found a related bug in Fedora bugzilla: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1697804

Also, there is a simple workaround there: modify the Super+Space key shortcut from changing input sources. You can just set it back to Super+Space. It'll remove XF86Keyboard shortcut from the shortcuts.

note.body:
OK, I think I found the bug: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/blob/master/src/st/st-entry.c#L1324

The callback for clean is connected in https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/blob/master/js/ui/viewSelector.js#L540, and the method which emits this signal connects to `button-release-event` to check if the icon was clicked. Likely we also need to connect to `touch-event`.

events.target_title: Shell OSD indicators are always empty

note.body:
I've checked instructions provided by @yhn1124 on both of my laptops. I'll call them 1 and 2.

1. I didn't have "User themes" enabled there. After enabling them and switching from the *Default* theme to Adapta-Nokto-Maia, the issue was fixed. Afterwards I installed `manjaro-gnome-assets` (which was the only package out of 3 mentioned on Manjaro Wiki that was not installed there, presumably because I installed Manjaro on that laptop in February 2018), and did not notice any changes.
2. I had "User themes" enabled there, but the *Default* theme was selected. After switching to Adapta-Nokto-Maia, the issue was fixed. All 3 of the packages mentioned on Manjaro Wiki had been installed there before.

I'm pretty sure I never switched from any custom themes to the *Default* one on either of these laptops.

Send newly-required parameters when registering for a scalar token
Do not show notification number for NickServ

Do not show notification number for NickServ

I didn’t mean notifications as actual notifications you receive when you do e.g. notify-send, but rather the counter that appears in polari itself:

events.target_title: Do not show notification number for NickServ
Kinetic scrolling
Kinetic scrolling

note.body:
To elaborate:

When libinput is used, GtkScrolledWindow is responsible for implementing kinetic scrolling and other gestures, however as the example of Firefox shows, this might not work if or when the scroll…ee(?) implements scrolling in a way that is not typical use of `GtkScrolledWindow`.

See [this](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/blob/e46a7ca70687b7ef15c237815bfe3f9269fc3956/gtk/gtkscrolledwindow.c#L270) and similar instances of "kinetic" in that file.

ref. https://wayland.freedesktop.org/libinput/doc/1.11.3/faq.html#faq_kinetic_scrolling

events.target_title: Kinetic scrolling

note.body: Also ref. https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1213601 for efforts to implement this functionality in Firefox.

events.target_title: Small fixes

note.body:
Hmm I read these bugs, maybe not carefully enough, but what I got from them was that we want to have
1 MB = 1.000.000 bytes
1 MiB = 1024*1024 bytes
and to be consistent about it.
The code I change is showing 4096 MB and is converting it to bytes by multiplying it by 1024*1024. If this is done on purpose, I missed where this was explained in these bugs :(
If you want to keep the MB unit, then I'd suggest
```
diff --git a/src/nautilus-file.c b/src/nautilus-file.c
index d4463178d..abf8a5e5f 100644
--- a/src/nautilus-file.c
+++ b/src/nautilus-file.c
@@ -85,7 +85,7 @@
 #define DEBUG_REF_PRINTF printf
 #endif
 
-#define MEGA_TO_BASE_RATE 1048576
+#define MEGA_TO_BASE_RATE 1000000
 
 /* Files that start with these characters sort after files that don't. */
 #define SORT_LAST_CHAR1 '.'
```

gnome-shell dies due to sigtrap when trying to start as wayland compositor
gnome-shell dies due to sigtrap when trying to start as wayland compositor

note.body:
Thanks for the support! :)
I do not get any other info in the journal regarding this that I can find, and `dbus-run-session -- gnome-shell --display-server --wayland` only returns -1.

However the issue seems connected to me having set `fish` to be `exec`ed even for non-interactive bash sessions using `which fish &>/dev/null && exec fish` in .bashrc.

After a change to only `exec` into fish if bash is interactive (`[[ $- == *i* ]]`) a wayland based session starts. So issue as such is "fixed" for me at least.

However it would have been nice with a error message of some kind (both in GDM and terminal) instead of complete silence when it fails to start due to user settings like this. I bet I'm not the first, and not the last to experience this (having non-standard shell enabled / issues in login scripts).

note.body:
I agree with the original poster - I've recently switched to Ubuntu 17.10, which uses the new nautilus, and the new search feature is very hard to get used to.

I nagivate my folder structure using type-ahead, and drill down through folders by typing a few letters of each folder, hitting enter, and then repeating, until I get to the folder I need - with the new search, this has become a very frustrating experience, and I hope the old type-ahead folder-select will be brought back in 18.04.

Can I tell which versions of a file actually differ in 3-way dir comparison?

note.body:
I'd like to help but having no Python experience I can hardly read the code. Any modification is completely beyond my skill level.

By "per-row-of-files" do you mean the 2 files in 2-way comparison and 3 files in 3-way comparison? Or is that function used for some other situations as well? I know it is not very nice and clean but wouldn't it be possible to check if 3 files are being compared and if so, the function wouldn't just return the state 'different' but rather one of 3 new states (like e.g. 'three_way_ssd', 'three_way_sds' and 'three_way_dss' where s=same and d=different)?

I realize it's probably more complicated than that. It's just an idea. Based on some questions on StackOverflow.com I believe this feature would make quite a few people happy.

Anyway, thanks for considering it and especially thanks for Meld! It's a really great tool!

>  Also, doing the only-bold-the-different-one thing is the hard bit here. Adding a new state for they're-all-different is a _lot_ less work, since we'd just need to... yeah... add a new state and handle it everywhere.

From my point of view, the "they're-all-different so let's make them orange" approach would be completely sufficient. I usually know which files I've modified so if the all-different rows were orange I wouldn't need to open the "blue" ones to be able to tell who changed them. And that would be a GREAT help!

        wrapper@resource:///org/gnome/gjs/modules/_legacy.js:82:22

        _clientGot@resource:///org/gnome/shell/ui/status/network.js:1663:9

events.target_title: icon network not showing in gnome-shell

note.body:
So I did some testing on this by overlaying the `/org/gnome/shell/ui/status/network.js` gresource using the `G_RESOURCE_OVERLAYS` environment variable with a file in my home folder to make changes and restart the shell after modifications to check what effect it had (I don't know if this is the best way to do it or not!).

It looks like the error relates to these couple of lines (426 and 427 of my gresource exported file, which seems to match the current `master`):

```javascript
                let item = this._connectionItems.get(this._activeConnection.connection.get_uuid());
                item.setActiveConnection(this._activeConnection);
```

Specifically, the `item.setActiveConnection(this._activeConnection);` throws the error. The UUID value in the line above **is** returned, but the `this._connectionItems.size` of the object map appears to be 0 and `item` ends up being `undefined`. I'm not sure if this object map being empty should be happening here so perhaps a GNOME dev or someone more knowledgable on what should be happening here can weigh on this.

Tentatively, I'm using the overlay on a modified file for a quick and dirty fix that does a check on `item` being `undefined` and only doing the `item.setActiveConnection` if it's not. This seems to restore the icon in the aggregateMenu and the text for the MenuItem in the menu. My change for line 427 for now is simply:

```javascript
if (item !== undefined) { item.setActiveConnection(this._activeConnection); }
```

events.target_title: icon network not showing in gnome-shell

note.body:
I hope it's not bad etiquette for me making another post here with more troubleshooting that I've done, but if it is then please let me know.

I did a little more investigation into this, to trace back to where `this._connectionItems` should be getting values added to it, which appears to be in the `_addConnection` function of the NMConnectionSection class, specifically line 305, which is:

```javascript
this._connectionItems.set(connection.get_uuid(), item);
```

From that same class, the `_addConnection` appears to be called from the `checkConnection` function, meaning that (assuming I'm understanding the code correctly) if the `_addConnection` is not called here, then no values are set for the `this._connectionItems`. What seems to happen in the case of the bridge connection is that the code does not continue past the first two lines of the `checkConnection` function:

```javascript
        if (!this._connectionValid(connection))
            return;
```

For me, `this._connectionValid(connection)` seems to returns false which in turn means that `!this._connectionValid(connection)` returns true, causing it to stop executing within the function and there not having a chance to call the `_addConnection` function. There is a `_connectionValid` function just above (line 248) that just returns true, but I assume it's related to the NMConnectionDevice class (subclass?) that extends the NMConnectionSection class overriding the `_connectionValid` function, however I will admit to not understanding as much about classes/subclasses here.

Hopefully the information is useful to someone to figure out the best way to handle this issue.

events.target_title: hard coded volume shortcut keys

note.body:
This seems like it would be useful, particularly in relation to the precise volume keys since I'm sure there has been previous conversation where people have expressed a desire to have finer control of volume steps. **Edit:** I don't mean to set both the precise/quiet keys to use the same `XF86Audio[Raise/Lower]Volume` binding without a modifier, I mean to expose this set of hard-coded volume bindings.

In place of the volume step itself not being configurable, since that has been decided against as far as I understand, the precise volume keys could be exposed as gsettings (along with the quiet volume keys requested here), so that a power user can adjust the shortcuts through `dconf`/`dconf-editor`.

If this is ok, I'm happy to create a merge request to make these available.

~~Additionally, is it preferable to avoid exposing the currently hard-coded shortcuts as gsettings here in general? I ask as there are other shortcuts I'd like to make configurable, specifically those related to power keys (sleep, suspend, etc.), though I can raise another issue for those.~~ **Edit:** Looks like someone's created a merge request for the power keys (!23)

events.target_title: [BZ#661768] [auto-move-windows] activate workspace after window was moved to it

note.body:
If there's any interest in this functionality being added, I've actually very recently worked on this myself locally (rather than having to use something like `devilspie`), though my approach has been to make it configurable per application, the same way the workspace number itself is. This does add to the data for each application looking something like `app-name.desktop:5:true`, where a `true` value indicates to switch to the workspace after moving the window.

I also added a little bit of code so that it neither moves an application, nor switches workspace if the application is already on the right workspace (according to the configuration), which in the instance of switching workspace, prevents a shell reload from switching you to another workspace (unless the application isn't on the one it should be, so to speak).

I would need to add some code to better handle older extension data (with only two values like `app-name.desktop:5`) and figure out an issue with the third preferences column not properly fitting inside the treeview area until you do some clicking around.

If not, that's fine too as I'm happy to keep my own version updated!

note.body:
Alright, I tested this in a VM with a stock Fedora Workstation 28 install (no updates) in a VM through libvirt (I'm using VMM to do so) to reproduce the issue. The ISO I used is "Fedora-Workstation-Live-x86_64-28-1.1.iso". Install Fedora in the VM and once installed and logged in, do the following:

- Press Alt+F2 and run `nm-connection-editor`
- Click `+` to add a connection
- For the initial Connection Type, select Bridge (Virtual > Bridge). Note: On the initial screen here, I disable STP because it slows down starting the connection.
- Under "Bridged connections:" click Add
- For the Connection Type, select Ethernet
- Click Create
- Select the sole network device (assuming there is only one for your VM) from the list under the "Device:" dropdown
- Click Save
- Click Save again
- Select the existing wired connection and remove it (leaving only bridge connections)
- Logout and back in, or restart

This should give you a working bridge inside the VM with connectivity, assuming your `virbr0` or whatever the default libvirt connection is, is active. The issue doesn't appear to affect the GDM login screen before login (I assume it's not connected to a network yet at that point?).

The above use of `nm-connection-editor` is essentially how I normally set up my bridge connection these days (though I change the connection names, but that's not necessary for these steps).
